Today we celebrate the 53rd anniversary of the signing of the landmark #VotingRightsAct, which prohibits voting discrimination against minorities. We must continue working to #RestoretheVRA and ensure every American citizen has the right to self-determination by casting a ballot. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Dj7j9m4VAAA1GcP.jpg

In 2013, the Supreme Court weakened  protections put in place by the #VRA to help voters of color pursue their basic right to cast a ballot on election day. Congress can and must take action to restore the Voting Rights Act. The foundation of our Democracy depends on it.

Many people associate the VRA with fighting voter suppression in the South but the law also had tangible impacts in NYC. It put an end to literacy tests in BK, Manhattan and the Bronx ‚Äì tests that disenfranchised Puerto Rican New Yorkers who were educated in Spanish.

On this day 53 years ago, the Voting Rights Act was signed into law. The law sought justice for voters of color who had been systemically disenfranchised. After SCOTUS gutted much of the law in 2013, it is incumbent upon Congress to #RestoretheVOTE.

On the left side of the door (top down), are scenes to represent Jurisprudence, Science, Fine Arts, & Mining. On the right side of the door (top down), are scenes that represent Agriculture, Iron & Electricity, Engineering, & Naval Architecture & Commerce. #CapitolHistory

The frame has oak and laurel leaves along the edge to symbolize strength and victory. In the transom, America is in a chariot pulled by two lions led by a child. This signifies the superiority of intellect over brute strength.

The transom at the top of the door, titled ‚ÄúApotheosis of America,‚Äù shows a figure of America surrounded by figural representations of painting, literature, music, education, commerce, mining, industry, and architecture.
